review.title: Towards Deep Semantic Analysis Of Hashtags
review.abstract: Hashtags are semantico-syntactic constructs used across various social networking and microblogging platforms to enable users to start a topic specific discussion or classify a post into a desired category. Segmenting and linking the entities present within the hashtags could therefore help in better understanding and extraction of information shared across the social media. However, due to lack of space delimiters in the hashtags (e.g #nsavssnowden), the segmentation of hashtags into constituent entities ("NSA" and "Edward Snowden" in this case) is not a trivial task. Most of the current state-of-the-art social media analytics systems like Sentiment Analysis and Entity Linking tend to either ignore hashtags, or treat them as a single word. In this paper, we present a context aware approach to segment and link entities in the hashtags to a knowledge base (KB) entry, based on the context within the tweet. Our approach segments and links the entities in hashtags such that the coherence between hashtag semantics and the tweet is maximized. To the best of our knowledge, no existing study addresses the issue of linking entities in hashtags for extracting semantic information. We evaluate our method on two different datasets, and demonstrate the effectiveness of our technique in improving the overall entity linking in tweets via additional semantic information provided by segmenting and linking entities in a hashtag.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Microblogging and social networking tags such as Twitter, Google +, Facebook and Instagram are becoming increasingly popular, with more than 400 million posts per day. This huge collection of posts on social media makes them an important source for collecting news and event information in real time. sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: The problem of word segmentation has been studied in various contexts in the past, and much work has been done on Chinese word segmentation. Huang et al. [3] demonstrated that the character-based tagging approach outperforms other word-based segmentation approaches for Chinese word segmentation, and English word segmentation has also been studied in the past by various researchers [2] [5] [6]. All such systems have examined length-specific characteristics to segment URLs into constituent chunks. [1] Although a particular hashtag can be divided into various possible segments, all of which are plausible, the "correct" segmentation depends on the tweet context. Consider, for example, a hashtag "notacon." It can be broken down into chunks "not, a, con" or "nota, con" based on the tweet context. The proposed system focuses on hashtag segmentation while it is contextual.

sections.heading: 3.3 Segmentation Ranker
sections.text: This component of the system is responsible for ranking the various probable segmentations seeded by the Hashtag Segmentation Seeder module. In the previous step, we generated five features for each segmentation with feature extraction and entity linking modules. These values are combined by modelling the problem as a regression problem, and the combined score is called ScoreRegression. Segmentations are classified using ScoreRegression. At the end, the Segmentation Ranker returns a ranking of the segmentations along with the entity associations. In the next section, we discuss the regression and training procedures in more detail.

sections.heading: 4 Training Procedure
sections.text: To train the model, we consider the score regression of all correct segments to be 1 and all false segmentations to be 0. Our feature vector consists of five different scores, which are calculated in Section 3.2. We use linear regression with elastic grid regularization [14], which allows us to learn a model that is trained with both L1 and L2 before regularizing. It also helps us to consider the situation in which some of the characteristics might be correlated. In this case ρ controls the convex combination of L1 and L2. sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Results
sections.text: In this section, we describe the data sets used for the analysis and determine the effectiveness of our technique by comparing our results with a well-known end-to-end entity linking system, TAGME [12], which works on short texts, including tweets.

sections.heading: 5.1 Evaluation Metrics and Datasets
sections.text: First, we explain the evaluation metrics in the context of our experiments, and second, we discuss the datasets used for the evaluation, and second, we discuss how we align our system with two different metrics. First, the system is evaluated based on its performance in the segmentation task of tweets. However, since the system returns a list of top k hashtag segmentations for a particular hashtag, we evaluate the accuracy of its linking based on the hashtag segmentation task. We also compared our P @ 1 score with Word Breaker5, which performs the task of word segmentation. Second, the system is evaluated based on its linking performance to the hashtags. We have precision, recall and F-measure scores for the entities linked in the top rankings, and for entity linking task tasks we have the same terms for the entities associated with each other, the precision, recall and F-measure scores.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have presented a context-aware method for segmenting a hashtag and linking its components to a knowledge base (KB), using a combination of syntactic and semantic characteristics to learn a regression model that provides a ranking of likely segmentation, allowing us to handle cases where 9 sets of data: http: / / bit.ly / HashtagDatamultiple segmentation (due to lack of context in cases where tweets are extremely short) are acceptable for the same hashtag, e.g. # Homesandgarden.The proposed method of extracting more semantic information from hashtags can be useful for many tasks, including, but not limited to, mood analysis, improving search in social networks and microblogs, topic recognition, etc.
